video.title: Full React Course 2020 - Learn Fundamentals, Hooks, Context API, React Router, Custom Hooks
video.description:
Learn the basics of React in this comprehensive course. You will learn about fundamentals, hooks, context API, react router, custom hooks, and more.

React is one of the most popular ways to build user interfaces using JavaScript.

🎥 React projects video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a_7Z7C_JCyo

✏️ Course from John Smilga of the Coding Addict channel. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/codingaddict

💻 Basic React Code: https://github.com/john-smilga/react-basics-2020
💻 Advanced React: https://github.com/john-smilga/react-advanced-2020

topLevelComment.author: Bipin Raj Sitoula
topLevelComment.text:
Just in case someone is stuck after cloning the react-advanced-2020, it might be happening because your node version might not be same as that used in the project. In that case, you need to locate package.json file and replace the "script". {...}  part on package.json file by the following:

"scripts": {
"start": "react-scripts --openssl-legacy-provider start",
"build": "react-scripts --openssl-legacy-provider build",
}

Once you do this, you may proceed with npm install and npm start command.

Hope this will help. Happy coding.
😊😊

topLevelComment.author: Muntean Ionut
topLevelComment.text: 09:54:50 - is the callback John passes to the `useCallback` hook a closure? Because it wraps the state of the `cart` variable at the moment of defining the function (ie: when the component renders). And thus that is why we need to pass the `cart` variable in the dependency array?

topLevelComment.author: Muntean Ionut
topLevelComment.text:
09:56:45 - why not do something like wrapping a callback that actually gets a parameter passed to it? As opposed to no paramater. Then, we would not have to account for checking when cart is updated.. right? 

Also, something more important. I am trying to wrap my head around why we must specify the cart variable in the dependency array. What I would like to point out (and hopefully shed some light for others on something I had it a bit more difficult to grasp) but please anyone correct me if I am wrong, is that: one should see the callback that John wraps with the useCallback call as a CLOSURE. That is, a function that has some state to it. Basically, when that function is created, its so-called “state” is going to be the value of the “cart” variable at that specific moment of creation. Then, whenever you would call that function( / “callback” ), it would simply get that initial value of the cart variable and increment it. Let’s say we call it again; then again, get the INITIAL value of cart (stored in the state of the function, as I said) and increment it. Basically, that function alone only keeps incrementing the same value over and over again. (Or am I wrong and this is not what happens, because useState takes care of incrementing the actual value of the cart variable - and by “actual” I mean “current”?) This is why in the dependency array we must include the reference to the cart variable.

Working in Windows.
When using it in some directory, instead of the desktop, 
npx create-react-app my-app 
Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, mkdir 'C:\Users\Home'
command not found: create-react-app

Solution: npm install -g create-react-app
then,
npx create-react-app <name the folder>

Maybe if ReactJS doesn't refresh your localhost  once you have saved your code, create a ".env" file in your root folder (in "tutorial" folder in this course) and then into it type :
FAST_REFRESH=false
Now close your VSCode and then open it again (This is important) ... and now the autorefresh for each save is gonna work

topLevelComment.author: Francis Akindejoye
topLevelComment.text:
If you're having a problem getting the starter project running, this was how I did mine...

After cloning from the GitHub repository... 

Firstly, I updated the "package.json" file to equal values with a recent project I was working on. Just copy and paste.

Example: I manually changed the react version to this value: "react": "^17.0.2". Not from the terminal. Did so with the rest.

Secondly, I deleted the "package-lock.json" from the project(the starter project).

Thirdly, I ran the command "npm install" on the terminal.

After that, I ran "npm start" to launch the server.

End.

I hope these steps help you.

topLevelComment.author: Alan Henrique
topLevelComment.text:
Guys I'm trying to learn react and I'm having an issue on VB Code setup.
Once I run "npm start" my default browser opens as should do.
Unfortunately it doesn't refresh/reload automacally as I edit and save my code.
Any help, pls?! Thx!!!

replies.author: Alan Henrique
replies.text: @DIDACTICS I've tried every basic action, even reinstall my w10. Afer hours searching for a solution, some guy pointed that's a bug and he also helped with a trick that works for me. Just create a ".env" file in your project root and add this parameter: FAST_REFRESH=FALSE. Save it and run npm. Thx for your answer.

topLevelComment.author: Richard Savala
topLevelComment.text:
I am currently working through John Smilga’s “Full React Course 2020 - Learn Fundamentals, Hooks, Context API, React Router, Custom Hooks” on freeCodeCamp’s YouTube channel: Full React Course 2020 - Learn Fundamentals, Hooks, Context API, React Router, Custom Hooks - YouTube

I am having issues with “Install Starter” (3:33:03) . When I type in npm install && npm start I get the following error:

npm WARN tsutils@3.17.1 requires a peer of typescript@>=2.8.0 || >= 3.2.0-dev || >= 3.3.0-dev || >= 3.4.0-dev || >= 3.5.0-dev || >= 3.6.0-dev || >= 3.6.0-beta || >= 3.7.0-dev || >= 3.7.0-beta but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself.

audited 1638 packages in 7.735s

67 packages are looking for funding
  run `npm fund` for details

found 84 vulnerabilities (82 moderate, 2 high)
  run `npm audit fix` to fix them, or `npm audit` for details

> tutorial@0.1.0 start /Users/owner/react-advanced-2020
> react-scripts start


There might be a problem with the project dependency tree.
It is likely not a bug in Create React App, but something you need to fix locally.

The react-scripts package provided by Create React App requires a dependency:

  "eslint": "^6.6.0"

Don't try to install it manually: your package manager does it automatically.
However, a different version of eslint was detected higher up in the tree:

  /Users/owner/node_modules/eslint (version: 7.25.0) 

Manually installing incompatible versions is known to cause hard-to-debug issues.

If you would prefer to ignore this check, add SKIP_PREFLIGHT_CHECK=true to an .env file in your project.
That will permanently disable this message but you might encounter other issues.

To fix the dependency tree, try following the steps below in the exact order:

  1. Delete package-lock.json (not package.json!) and/or yarn.lock in your project folder.
  2. Delete node_modules in your project folder.
  3. Remove "eslint" from dependencies and/or devDependencies in the package.json file in your project folder.
  4. Run npm install or yarn, depending on the package manager you use.

In most cases, this should be enough to fix the problem.
If this has not helped, there are a few other things you can try:

  5. If you used npm, install yarn (http://yarnpkg.com/) and repeat the above steps with it instead.
     This may help because npm has known issues with package hoisting which may get resolved in future versions.

  6. Check if /Users/owner/node_modules/eslint is outside your project directory.
     For example, you might have accidentally installed something in your home folder.

  7. Try running npm ls eslint in your project folder.
     This will tell you which other package (apart from the expected react-scripts) installed eslint.

If nothing else helps, add SKIP_PREFLIGHT_CHECK=true to an .env file in your project.
That would permanently disable this preflight check in case you want to proceed anyway.

P.S. We know this message is long but please read the steps above :-) We hope you find them helpful!

npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno 1
npm ERR! tutorial@0.1.0 start: `react-scripts start`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the tutorial@0.1.0 start script.
npm ERR! This is probably not a problem with npm. There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /Users/owner/.npm/_logs/2021-05-10T18_57_38_644Z-debug.log


I have tried the suggested steps in the error message with no success, as well as some suggestions from stackoverflow and freeCodeCamp's forum. I also downloaded GitHub Desktop thinking it might help. Any suggestions are appreciated!

What we need is just only one evertListener to listen to the window resize event.

topLevelComment.author: Blonduos
topLevelComment.text: I am currently on UseEffect, lesson 2, Cleanup function. Instead of the cleanup function to prevent addEventListener being added infinitely, I just added an empty array after the useEffect arrow function. My addEventListener only ran once, but my front-end width was changing as I was changing my window size as it should. Can anyone explain if this is an ok thing to do, or could it cause other issues (so the useEffect basically ran only once, instead of the cleanup function which cleaned up the eventlisteners)

replies.author: José Manuel Hernández
replies.text: He actually explained that later, passing an empty array as second argument can fix that issue if the component persists in the app, but if the component is unmounted (remove an item from a list for example) it won't fix it as the event will remain in memory.

4- Now you should be able to run scripts

topLevelComment.author: Qiexie f
topLevelComment.text:
If you have problems with hot-reload, and your react page doesn't update automatically with any changes, but the npm server compiles it without any errors, you can create a file named ".env" in the root project directory (where you hgave src folder, public folder ect), and you wanna write "FAST_REFRESH=false" into this new file.

topLevelComment.author: Shoshana T
topLevelComment.text: Could anyone explain what a "dependency" is? I'm at the beginning of the video and the term is being used.

replies.author: Shoshana T
replies.text: @libyMath  @Raghu Raj Rai  Thanks, both! This makes more sense now. I assume this is a general coding term then, that's not just specific to React, but is used with any coding framework that "depends" on a separate... framework/software/bit of code (not sure which?) to run.

replies.author: libyMath
replies.text: He is referring to the "node modules" which contain the react modules that allow you to use ReactJS. This is because usually when using "create-react-app" they are installed automatically, but in the case of cloning the repository from GitHub he did not include his node modules because they might have conflicted with your system. To install the dependencies command line over to the "react-examples" clone and then run the command "npm install" to install the dependencies.

replies.author: Raghu Raj Rai
replies.text: It's basically a requirement. Consider package X which is built using package Y. Now if you want to install package X and use it, you'll also need to install package Y since it is a dependency of package X. If it's still not clear, let me know in what context you'd like for me to explain.

Worked for me on Windows10/Chrome, "react": "^17.0.1" 
Happy coding :)

topLevelComment.author: Manzour Abdalla
topLevelComment.text:
what kind of error this is ?

Error: Book(...): Nothing was returned from render. This usually means a return statement is missing. Or, to render nothing, return null.

replies.author: Deep
replies.text: Check your return statement from Book function definition. It needs to return a single JSX element. And the opening tag of that single element needs to be on the same line where the return statement lies. So wrap the element in parantheses and make sure the first parentheses is in the same line where the return statement lies and then you can put your element in the next line.

topLevelComment.author: El Mehdi Seddougui
topLevelComment.text: in the custom hooks section (8:36:00), why do we get this warning: "React Hook useEffect has a missing dependency: 'getProducts'. Either include it or remove the dependency array " and why would we need to add it to the dependency array?

replies.author: El Mehdi Seddougui
replies.text: according to the react documentation, the reason the function "getProducts" must be declared in the dependency array is because it depends on a prop or state variable (url in this case). It is advised to move the "getProducts" function inside the the useEffect hook to avoid getting the warning.

topLevelComment.author: Toufiqul Islam
topLevelComment.text:
Hello Sir,
I am absolutely a newbie in the arena of programming. So, my question maybe make you embarrassing; but I want to learn and I want to know:
(1) What is the relation or difference among the React, React JS, and React Native?
(2) If anyone wants to be a Rect Native expert then is there any necessity to learn React JS or React?
Please, Kindly answer my questions.

replies.author: Sandeepan Bhattacharyya
replies.text: It's a simple google search. ReactJS is a set of modules written in JavaScript to deal with UI development. React is the library that has the basic components for the task. React-DOM is the module that deals with webpages UI development. React-Native is a module used for developing Mobile apps using ReactJS. React-360 is a module that deals with VR UI development. And so on...
